articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s 15,000 New Emails to Get Timetable for Release
articles.snippet: A federal judge on Monday ordered the State Department to set a timetable to release new emails uncovered during an inquiry into her private server.
articles.abstract: A federal judge on Monday ordered the State Department to set a timetable to release new emails uncovered during an inquiry into her private server.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The dispute over Hillary Clinton’s email practices now threatens to shadow her for the rest of the presidential campaign after the disclosure on Monday that the F.B.I. collected nearly 15,000 new emails in its investigation of her and a federal judge’s order that the State Department accelerate the documents’ release.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: ‘It Had to Be Stopped’: Heroes Rise Amid France Terror Attacks
articles.snippet: Some ordinary people in France have reacted heroically, risking their lives by fighting terrorists when they found themselves in the midst of an attack.
articles.abstract: Some ordinary people in France have reacted heroically, risking their lives by fighting terrorists when they found themselves in the midst of an attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICE, France — Terrorist attacks in France come often enough that they can seem to be variations on a painful pattern: carnage followed by disbelief, then condemnations, condolences, and shrines of flowers, candles and letters for the dead.

articles.headline: Inside the Conservative Push for States to Amend the Constitution
articles.snippet: Advocacy groups are calling for states to meet and discuss a federal balanced-budget amendment. A clause in the U.S. Constitution makes the proposal possible.
articles.abstract: Advocacy groups are calling for states to meet and discuss a federal balanced-budget amendment. A clause in the U.S. Constitution makes the proposal possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taking advantage of almost a decade of political victories in state legislatures across the country, conservative advocacy groups are quietly marshaling support for an event unprecedented in the nation’s history: a convention of the 50 states, summoned to consider amending the Constitution.

articles.headline: High-Price Ethanol Credits Add to Refiners’ Woes
articles.snippet: The cost of credits for renewable fuels is soaring, hurting the profits and share prices of independent refiners that do not add biofuels to their products.
articles.abstract: The cost of credits for renewable fuels is soaring, hurting the profits and share prices of independent refiners that do not add biofuels to their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUGAR LAND, Tex. — The oil-refining business has always been a tough way to make money.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, Ages 68 and 70, Share Few Health Details
articles.snippet: Breaking from recent tradition, both nominees are proving relatively secretive and selective in providing up-to-date medical records.
articles.abstract: Breaking from recent tradition, both nominees are proving relatively secretive and selective in providing up-to-date medical records.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton have been more secretive and selective than many recent presidential nominees in providing up-to-date details about their personal health — a particularly striking departure, experts say, given the candidates’ age.

articles.headline: After Failed Coup, Turkey Enjoys a Rare Period of Unity
articles.snippet: Many Turks have put aside political differences after a failed military uprising — although some may be motivated by fear in the wake of the president’s purge of suspected political enemies.
articles.abstract: Many Turks have put aside political differences after a failed military uprising — although some may be motivated by fear in the wake of the president’s purge of suspected political enemies.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey is normally a divisive figure, loved by his base of religious conservatives and loathed by the rest of society. But there he was recently, sipping tea and making easy chitchat with his political rivals, just before joining them in a rally this month on Istanbul’s waterfront to celebrate the failure of an attempted military coup.

articles.headline: Egyptians Take to the Streets Again, Now in Workout Gear
articles.snippet: For a country where smoking is everywhere and obesity and diabetes are rampant, a new fitness revolution has been a stark departure.
articles.abstract: For a country where smoking is everywhere and obesity and diabetes are rampant, a new fitness revolution has been a stark departure.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s young people have once again taken to the streets. This time, though, they are in spandex and on bicycles, in kayaks and sculls on the Nile, doing street workouts in the slums of Giza or CrossFit exercises in makeshift rooftop gyms.
